AND THEN FURTHER IMAGES FROM THE BURGEONING DISPUTE ARE
INTER-CUT WITH MORE NEWSPAPER ARTICLES. THEY START SMALL

text: Rita addresses a crowd of onlookers. Thirty or so girls are gathered around her, including Connie and Sandra who hold up a banner proclaiming: SUPPORT THE FORD MACHINISTS. Passing are a group of West Ham fans on the way to a match with scarves and rattles. Several stop and listen. Rita sounds much smoother.

‘Cause basically, Ford’s done what they have, awarded us a pay cut, ‘cause they think no-one’1ll really notice, because we’re women. And women’s pay has always been less than men’s... MORE HEADLINES: PETTICOAT REBELLION GROWS etc.

Gordon and Frank arrive at the River Plant’s deserted warehouse area on the forklift. They swing open two massive doors. Inside, the store is packed with thousands of finished headrests, seat covers and door trim. Both men look at each other ruefully.
Rita addresses a mass of workers. She is noticeably more confident and slicker.
And that’s a tactic, not just the Ford Management, but all managements have exploited, year after year: basin’ huge profits on a wage system which is as corrupt as it is unchallenged-
A couple of men glance at each other and nod; fair point. HEADLINE: FORD STRIKERS LEAD WOMEN’S RIGHTS MOVE
Which begs the question, why? Why is it like that? And the answer is, us! Because we've never said no.

In the more modern main plant, we see Albert, then Dave who is holding up a copy of the Dagenham and Redbridge Echo. BANNER HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT DENY CRISIS. Then we hear Rita’s voice, gliding, over the picture.

We've meekly stepped forwards, despite what we've seen with our mothers and our grandmothers and we’ve taken our pay packets and we’ve tugged our forelocks and we’ve said “thank you very much.” Well, no more! The time has come for all women to say: Enough! We do not accept this! We hear applause. And see Eddie, smiling bashfully, as a picture of Rita, campaigning, is pointed out to him, beneath the banner.
The applause fades as Rita steps down from the platform. She is immediately approached by several reporters and other union officials.

Rita... She turns. Albert indicates a young man who stands away from the crush. ALBERT (CONT’D) There's a bloke here from The Times. Rita tries not to react. MUSIC ENDS EXT. TOOLEY’S OFFICE - DAY 64 A copy of The Times lies on the polished desk in Tooley’s office. Tooley sits on one side of the desk and on the other is a man with a leathery face and buzz cut hair. Both men stare at a plastic box in the middle of the desk. It is perforated with dark holes and has a thick power cord running from it. Suddenly, from the box, a silky smooth woman's voice emanates
10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 47aA

Mr. Hardey is ready to speak now gentlemen. Thank you so much for waiting. Tooley and Kronnfeld glance at each other. A click. But then nothing. Kronnfeld loses his nerve and leans forward to speak. He’s beaten to it-
I though your boy said he could handle this? Kronnfeld stiffens. JEB HARDEY, sixty, boss of Ford America, has a gruff, blue collar voice.

And do we even know what we’re dealing with here? Socialist Workers Party; Workers Revolutionary Party; Revolutionary Communist Party?... Who's she with? Kronnfeld glances quickly at the impassive Tooley and then down, dry mouthed, to an open file on his desk; it is the duplicate of the one before Tooley. A picture of Rita is uppermost on both. Kronnfeld takes a breath and does his best.
We don’t think she’s with anyone, Sir. We don’t even think she’s a communist. She’s looks like she’s-

-She looks like Rita Heyworth, goddamit, I don’t care! I wanna know why she’s acting like this! Kronnfeld sits back, wide eyed. He’s done. He’s given it his best shot. Tooley, unimpressed by Kronnfeld’s disintegration, leans closer to the communications box-
The fact is, sir... she hasn’t got a background in politics, in or outside the union... her husband’s a moderate, so... we think she’s just got a beef-

A beef! That’s what she’s got? Bobby, if this woman gets what she wants and Ford Motors is forced to introduce equal pay for men and women in the UK... we’ll end up havin’ to do it right across the world! (threatening) Do you understand that?
10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 47aB
Yes, sir.
So deal with it! Now! A click. Beat. Kronnfeld looks like a man who has been involved in a road accident. But, then he sighs relief as he turns to Tooley
I guess you'll be getting the next flight outta here Bobby?
Mrs Castle sighs, frustrated.

Prime Minister...I’m not sure you quite appreciate the urgency of the situation... as of 5pm yesterday there were 405 strikes in progress nationally... Harold Wilson turns. He has a dog on a lead. Mrs Castle looks at it distastefully. Wilson considers Mrs Castle and then walks on. She follows, struggling, as her heels sink into the grass. Two of her undersecretaries follow her. She stops suddenly. Because Wilson has stopped. Because the dog is taking a crap. He looks at it fondly. Mrs Castle winces; would say more. But Wilson is delighted by the distraction.
It's always white when he goes to the toilet. Yet he never eats anything white. (Mrs Castle is stunned) Mary gives him the odd fruit gum-
Prime Minister! He hears her aggrieved tone; looks across, awkwardly.
I’m not saying I won't legislate. Just- The dog now trots on. Wilson gladly follows. And Mrs. Castle, too! She will not be deflected-
What? We’ve talked about this a hundred times... Until you introduce new bills, which give me the power to regulate the Unions, I cannot get the country back to work-—
I understand that... (she looks hopeful) But we need to tread carefully; draw the unions in- Her heart sinks. The Undersecretary leans in.
We have to acknowledge that without the unions there would be no Labour Party- She stops; so does he.

Young man! I was a member of the Trades Union Movement while you were still at your Mother’s breast... so unless you have something to add which goes beyond the blindingly obvious, I'd prefer it if you kept quiet! He slinks off. Mrs Castle totters on, catching up with Wilson. She tries a different tone.
Harold- He looks down. She has put her hand on his wrist.
-You asked me to do this job; you appointed me-
You’re the best man in my cabinet, Barbara, I often say that- He laughs nervously. But his joke hasn't deflected her. She’s staring at him. ALL woman.
I can’t do it without you, Harold- Wilson finally turns away, graps a stick at throws it for the dog.
I need you to... Wilson stops dead. Then, from a dry throat, Wilson croaks

Jack Scamp! (her face falls) He’s your man. Any... impasse... get Jack in. Sits them all round a table; beer and pork pie. Straight talking negotiation... (nods ) He’s the way forward. Mrs Castle takes a deep breath and nods. Seduction failed, she’s back in war mode.

Beer and pork pie... Might not do for the latest one. Down at Ford. (Wilson frowns) 187 Machinists. All women... Perhaps get a finger buffet in, eh? She turns, starts to walk, sinks, takes of her shoes then strides back across the lawn, thunderous.

A city gent, in suit and bowler, stands silently with many other commuters on their regular run into the City. He looks uneasy. And as we pass along his carriage, we see the girls crushed at its far end, chatting excitedly, their protest paraphernalia causing considerable disruption. The city gent looks distastefully away. But then he leaps and his hand goes to his backside. Someone has pinched his arse. Then we see Brenda, close by. She smiles sweetly. EXT. LONDON TUBE -—- DAY 67A The girls emerge from the tube, blinking into the bright sunlight. They are gossiping madly, excited and some, a little overawed.
Come on, then, girls! Get yourselves organised!
Anyone fancy a Wimpy?...I’m starvin’- Rita turns, distracted-
We ain’t got time to see the sites, have we?
No, we have not! Now Sandra appears in tiny shorts and a skimpy top. She looks round, urgently.
Where’s all the press, then?
We ain’t there yet!
We gotta get to parliament first, you silly sod-
(frustrated) Exactly!
So?...Which way is it?
Rita looks round. Then she sighs, having to come clean-
(to girls) I think it’s this way, isn’t it? The girls all look in different directions. Clearly no one knows.
The girls arrive on a small lawned area outside the Houses of Parliament.
Alright, ladies! This is a good spot. Form up! They put down their bags and begin unfurling the banners.
INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY 69 Mrs Castle sighs. She is leafing through more reports of industrial unrest. Then she becomes aware of the pips outside-
The girls are gathered with their banners. A car toots... and another. The girls wave. Men shout encouragement. A driver leans from the cab of a passing van and calls across.
Here, I finish work at four. Give us a call! His mate laughs. The girls wave back, blithely. More people react and the girls shout back, giddy with excitement.
It’s unbelievable... I never thought we’d get this backing- More pips and Rita frowns. She looks up, at the banner she holds. A moment.

Girls...I think we’re not entirely unfurled. All of them look up to the banner. It says: WE WANT SEX INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WHITEHALL OFFICES - DAY 71 Mrs Castle looks out of her window. Sees the banner.
I know the feeling. She walks back to her stressful work.

Outside we see Connie help Rita frantically untwist the banner. WE WANT SEX EQUALITY is revealed. Rita, flustered, gestures for the girls to re-group. Most are giggling. Reporters and photographers are approaching.
Through the laughter, Sandra is suddenly aware that photographers are taking pictures. She skips over to them. Rita turns to the approaching press.

Go on, Rita! Tell ‘em how it is!- But Rita is already stepping forward to meet the advance as Sandra poses, off to one side. The others stand and watch as Rita is engulfed by reporters. A man approaches Brenda. He is scruffy, bearded. He looks at her.
Hello. Brenda looks at him. She’s never seen anyone like him before.

Hello. He hands her a leaflet from a pile he is holding. She looks at it. It’s about a political rally. When she looks back up he is gone. The photographers finally finish taking pictures of Sandra, she comes over.
It's quite interesting, politics. When you get down to it.

head_text.subj: A TV IMAGE. OF THE PROTEST JUST SEEN, OUTSIDE PARLIAMENT.

text: What makes this strike different- -is that it’s not about a specific pay settlement-
REPORTER (CONT’D) -but the whole issue of sex discrimination-

head_text.subj: RITA. SHE IS BEING JOSTLED OUTSIDE
WESTMINSTER. FLASH BULBS POP AROUND HER AND MICROPHONES

text: A cheer in the background. And ON SCREEN we see- REPORTER (CONT’D) How long are the girls prepared to stay out?
It must be starting to bite now-
As long as it takes-
Does your husband support you in all this? Another cheer in the background.
He has to!
He...supports me...We always support the men when they come out.
What about the other Ford women; in Liverpool? Are they behind you?
They will be. Several reporters call out. One persists.
Does it bother you you’ve been described as a Revlon Revolutionary?
Have they been in touch? About doing some modelling work for them. Laughter from the reporters. Rita smiles.
I prefer to concentrate on the issues of the strike-

head_text.subj: A PHOTO FLASHES. RITA TURNS HER HEAD TOWARDS IT. THEN THE

text: -After the March protests in Grosvenor Square, this months student riots in Paris- TV PICTURE IS REPLACED BY A TEST MATCH.
Ha! Ain’t that somethin’?
Dave and Eddie turn from the TV, pints in hand.
Yeah. She’s doin’ alright.
And she mentioned you...On the television... (jabs finger at Eddie) You gotta smart woman there, Eddie. Eddie nods, uneasily. Then smiles. He glances at his watch.
I gotta get goin’-
Already?
I know...I gotta fetch the kids... (Dave frowns) Rita reckons they won’t be back ‘til gone six, so...I need to get ‘em sorted. He smiles ruefully at Dave and downs his pint.
You tell her to get her finger out. When you see her.
55 And for the first time we notice George, sitting on a stool by the bar. He stares at his half of mild, not looking at Dave or Eddie.
Gone on long enough now.
(laughing) I don’t think they're deliberately draggin’ it out, George-
It's alright for you and him. Two wages in the house. I’ve got me war pension and I’ve got what she earns. That’s it...I can’t afford a bastard strike.
I know that...And they’1l settle it; soon as they can. George says nothing more. Eddie nods and goes.
A coach pulls up outside a factory gate. On it is 74 written: FORD, HALEWOOD. Rita gets off. Several of the girls follow.
75 Rita stands on a soap box outside the main factory. She is sweating, passionate, addressing a crowd of women.

-You’re doin’ the same work for Ford, here in Liverpool, that we’re doin’ for ‘em down in Dagenham. So you know that our job is skilled...But I’m askin’ you to think beyond that...I’m askin’ you to strike now for all women, not just machinists, until every one of us gets fairness and is entitled to the same pay as men!...Will all those in favour, put their hands in the air now, please- They do. Rita beams, delighted.

The kids sit at the dining room table. Smoke spills from the kitchen. They glance at each other. Look slightly worried. INT. RITA’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - EARLY EVENING 77 The kitchen is a mess as Eddie, sweat dripping from his nose, tries to fry a piece of liver. A huge flame leaps up from under the pan as spitting oil hits the gas. Eddie leaps back, cursing, then goes back to the food, his jaw tight.

Eddie drops newspaper wrapped fish and chips onto Sharon's plate. Sharon glances at Graham. She is struggling not to snigger as she undoes the package and takes a chip. Graham laughs out loud as he receives his bundle of food. Eddie looks thoroughly pissed off.

The girls drive back from Halewood. Rita, sitting at the front, with Connie beside her, glances out over burnished countryside, a low red sun throbbing in the sky. Across the aisle, also at the front, Sandra has a transistor radio on her lap, a single ear piece in. She starts to sing, quietly as she looks out of the window-

Once upon a time, there was a tavern, where we used to raise a glass or two- (Brenda, next to her, looks across) Remember how we laughed away the hours- Brenda starts to sing. And then Connie joins in.
Think of all the great things we would do- Rita sings. And others, too. Sandra realises, then, smiling, continues in full voice with the rest:

Those were the days, my friend, We thought they'd never end, We'd sing and dance forever and a day- (Rita laughs) We'd live the life we'd choose, We'd fight and never lose, For we were young and sure to have our way-
The bus slips through the warm, summer night-
La La La La La La-
Hopkins opens his front door and approaches Tooley, who is getting out of a taxi.
Welcome. How was your flight?
Long.
I’m so sorry to drag you over.
They're taking this very seriously. Right at the top.
Come in. My wife’s cooking dinner... They walk into the house.
Hopkins passes into a modern, late sixties, detached house. Tooley follows.
Really, I don’t want to be any trouble.
Honestly...Least I can do...Let me take your coat. Hopkins wife appears in a pinny. Lisa. HOPKINS (CONT’D) Lisa...This is Robert Tooley-
Delighted to meet you at last.
Likewise. They shake. Then Hopkins hands Tooley’s coat to Lisa.
I was saying to Peter; I’m quite happy to eat later; at the hotel-

Nonsense! She loves to cook. (glances at Lisa) Don’t you?..Just relax. Have a drink. I’11 run you back when we’re finished. Hopkins passes his coat to Lisa too and ushers Tooley through into the sitting room. Lisa looks at the coats and then hangs them up. INT. RITA’S HOUSE - NIGHT 83 Rita walks into the house, excited. The place is chaotic but it seems hardly to register as she smiles, seeing Eddie arriving at the foot of the stairs. He bends stiffly to pick up some clothes, then straightens and spots her. She beams.
Go alright, then?
I slaughtered ‘em! Every single one come out!
Well done. He moves into the kitchen and starts to collect the plates. She follows.

It was incredible though, Eddie! To start with. A load of ‘em said, while they was happy to support their fellow machinists...union solidarity and all that...they didn’t actually agree with equal pay as a principal. Men deserved more...Can you believe that? He looks at her; her ebullience. And suddenly feels troubled. But he manages a smile.
I’‘1l go and check on the kids. Give ‘ema quick kiss. She pecks him on the cheek and goes. He stares at the cluttered table. His effort. Anger swells.
Yeah. I managed alright. Thanks.
Lisa clears away. Bottles of beer sit on the table.
Thank you.
Can you bring some brandy glasses back in with you? She nods and smiles. Then turns to go.
Lisa...You must have a quite head on your shoulders...Peter tells me you read history. At Cambridge-
Yeah- She nods, proudly but then suddenly becomes aware of the plates in her hand. She puts them on the sideboard.
So whadda you make of our little problem; over at the factory? (nods to Peter) Think maybe he’s a bit too much velvet glove and not enough iron fist? She seems uncertain, then shrugs, relaxing.

I don’t actually. Just the opposite. Look at Vauxhall. They don’t appear to have any problem with the unions and that seems to me because General Motors have a much more collaborative approach to Management. Whereas at Ford, you seem only to deal with the unions because you have to...You tolerate them. And as a result they’re much more entrenched and aggressive in the way that they deal with you. Tooley looks at her. Then he smiles.

That’s a very...progressive point of view, Lisa. (turns to alarmed Hopkins) Isn't it? He stares at Hopkins, his expression at once benign but threatening. Hopkins hesitates, then turns to Lisa. He smiles, but it’s a fragile thing. Then-
Cheese.
What?
We've...got some Stilton...Why don’t you...get that out?...Some grapes. Lisa is wrong footed. She looks to Tooley for support. He doesn’t meet her eye.
That'd be terrific. Hopkins smiles, relieved. Lisa colours; she is dismissed. She picks up the plates, glances at her husband and leaves the room.

Lisa drops the plates into the sink and leans back against the draining board, trembling. On the table is a copy of the Daily Mail, it’s headline: FORD WOMEN FIGHT ON. Beneath it is a picture of a rally and a woman speaking out. There is something familiar about the woman. Lisa crosses and picks up the paper. Her face - as she sees it is Rita. EXT/INT. RITA’S HOUSE - DAY 86 Rita checks the temperature on the oven. Then she crosses to her bag which is on a chair beside the set kitchen table and removes her purse. It is empty. Her jaw tightens and she crosses to a cupboard near the door. Inside is a metal box, full of shoe polish, cloths and brushes. Also in there is a puncture repair kit. She opens this and reveals some crumpled notes and a few coins. She takes some of the cash, not all, and shoves it into her wallet. She grabs her bag and hurries into the hall.
Graham is coming downstairs.
It’s in the oven. Don’t burn yourself-

He wordlessly moves into the kitchen. And Rita pulls on a jacket. She turns and stops. Sharon is there. Her hair is in pig tails. One bunch is massively bigger than the other, while one is a tangled mess.
What happened?
Dad. Rita stares and goes towards her. Then she stops.
I gotta go see Albert. Just tell him to have another go. Sharon slips into the kitchen and Rita ties on a head scarf as Eddie comes down the stairs. She nods to the kitchen.
‘s all ready... (crosses to placards against wall) You’re alright gettin’ ‘em off to school, aren't you? He watches her pick up the placards.
Course. She turns. Immediately he moves towards the kitchen.
Eddie- (he stops) Everything’s okay, innit? He stares at her, then shrugs.
Yeah. Why wouldn’t it be? She smiles, relieved and moves to the door. He watches her, then fingers the collar of his shirt.
This is me last one.
What?
Shirt. I just noticed.
(wrong footed) Yeah...Sorry. I missed washin’ Monday. I’1l do it tonight. He nods. And walks into the kitchen. A second. Rita stares at the empty doorway then leaves.
The girls are queuing up for strike pay which Connie hands out from a table near the stage. There is much banter between the girls.
Rita passes Connie a sheet with names on it and removes one covered with signatures.
Thanks Rita- A young woman steps forward-
Monica Dawson-
There you go- She passes her the list. She signs and then Rita hands her three notes. Monica stares at the money.
It’s still three quid, love. Don’t matter how you count it!
I know...just...’bout covers me rent and that’s it-
Hey, Mon; you’re short of anything, you just gotta ask- Eileen is next in line. Monica smiles, grateful. But then she shakes her head.
No. I’m alright. Thanks. I’1l manage.
It’s all the Union can afford, Monica... She nods. She knows that. And she goes, slipping the money in her purse. Eileen steps forward-

Eileen Scott. She bends over to sign. Brenda waits two or three girls behind her and lights a cigarette. She sucks greedily on the fag, then notices a woman waiting behind her, about thirty, looking longingly at the fag-

It’s me last one. Sorry, love. She shows her the empty packet. The girl smiles, disappointed. She nods, looks ahead, towards Connie. Brenda sighs. She takes her cigarette from her mouth, and tears it in two.
She lights one end against the other and then gives half to the girl who beams, delighted.

Monty stands with Grant and Hopkins. He tries to look confident. In fact, he’s uneasy. The whole room is. Then, suddenly, the door bursts open and Tooley strides in, a file under one arm. He slings it onto a far desk as Hopkins tries to assert control.
Monty. This is Mr Tooley. He-
I need you to break the strike for me, Mr Taylor...As soon as you can. Monty glances at Hopkins who also looks a little surprised. Monty scoffs.
I’m not sure you appreciate whose side I’m on-
Oh, yes, I do. I’ve been going through your file-
File?
You’re on your side, Mr Taylor.
I beg your pardon!? I- (to Hopkins) I don’t have to listen to this- He moves towards the door
Keep going! And six months from now, your union won't exist. Monty stops. Despite himself. He turns back.

Industry can’t afford to pay women the same rates as men. Fact. If it’s forced to, it will collapse under the extra wage bill, its workers will be laid off, their union subscriptions will disappear and so, finally, will the unions which collect them. That’s you...Monty. (MORE)

Which means you will no longer have a reason to visit these gentlemen here via- (flips open file) The Berni Inn, is it?...The Queen’s Head, The Chequers- (looks up) Jeez, that’s a lot’ve restaurants...Not to mention the all expenses paid trips to the party conferences. Union conferences- (spots something) To Paris! The Gallic rank and file. Good on you, Monty! Monty blinks; afraid. Tooley walks across and leans right into him.

These women get what they want, you’re fucked. So why don’t you start thinking less about what your union can do for you and more what you can do for your union...Go break the strike! Monty trembles, humiliated, then walks numbly from the office. A long silence. Tooley looks to the others.
Personnel files...Everyone’s got a weak spot. You just gotta find it.

The women are now on picket before their entrance gates. They call out for Equal Pay, Equality... several chant; ‘We Want Justice!’ and ‘Support Our Struggle!’ A lorry delivering supplies turns away in support of them. the Women all cheer. The lorry pips as it drives back up the road. As the lorry accelerates away Rita sees a figure approaching-—

Hello, love! Thought you weren’t comin’- (hands across money) Got your strike pay. Albert let me have it- Connie looks at it, takes it and nods. But she is hassled. She places her bag on the kerb beside several others, then steps across to join the chatting girls. Rita lowers her voice.
You alright?

Yeah...Fine. Connie looks up the road. But she is aware of Rita staring at her; not convinced. Connie sighs, then steps back to rummage in her bag: a diversion. Rita moves over. Connie lowers her voice.
-Was a load've press outside the Labour Exchange. They cornered George... (Rita is confused) “Had he fought for a country where the women’d turn out to be more militant than the men?”-—
Silly sods. Connie frowns; that’s not what she meant.
Yeah. But then, a bell sounds briefly. Rita looks across. A dark blue police van pulls up.
What they doin’ here? Three or four policemen get out of the van.
Hello boys. Nothin’ too physical. Til we're on first name terms. I’m Brenda- The girls all laugh. A young PC, about twenty, speaks:
You gotta move. The hilarity stops in an instant.
What?
You’re trespassin’.
No, we ain’t. We're picketin’-
You can’t. Not here.
(annoyed) Yes, we can. It’s our right!
Not here! He is firm. The girls are stunned.

You can do it at the bottom of the High Street-— (points way back to town) But this road, all the way back to town, Ford built. So it’s private property and since you’re on strike you’re actually out of contract which means you are trespassin’. You gotta move to the public highway-
We can’t turn the lorries round from there-
I’m sorry!...Look, who’s in charge? Everyone looks at Rita but Connie steps forward.
I’m shop steward- Rita turns, wrong footed-
Right. I need you to get these women out of here. He nods and then opens his arms wide as if to corral the women up the road-
Get your hands off me-
I ain’t touched you-
It’s alright, Connie-
No. It ain’t alright!
(to Connie) Will you just move-
No! Rita is worried, the situation starting to boil-
Yeah, sod off! We ain’t doin’ nothin’ wrong- The women link arms. Connie is on the end of the line.
You are! And you gotta shift! He shoves Connie forwards. She pulls away.
Get off me! You ignorant bugger-
Right! Lads- He beckons the other coppers. And grabs Connie.
Leave her!

Get off! Come here- Connie kicks her heel hard into his shin. He cries out, letting go. But the other coppers grab her as the girls shove back against them. A huge melee ensues. The press take photos and Sandra tries to smile, even as she’s shoved one way and the other. In a moment, though, Connie, screaming, is extracted, shoved in the van and the coppers are away. Silence immediately falls and Rita looks to Brenda, shocked.
Monty stands looking out of a window at the aftermath of the skirmish. A pay phone is close by, on the wall. Monty feels sick.

INT. CONNIE’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 92 A clock ticks. And ticks. Then we see George. He sits at home. He is in an armchair but is perched right on the edge of the seat. He looks at the time. Then back to a spot on the far wall. He suddenly screws his eyes tight shut and grimaces. A second and he opens his eyes again. Wherever he is, he’s utterly terrified.
Brenda, Rita and Eileen are all piled into the station and Rita speaks to the uniformed desk clerk. She is incredulous.
You can’t just keep her in.
We can do what we like while she’s hysterical-
Course she’s hysterical! She’s been in a bleedin’ police cell all afternoon- (gathers her own emotions) Please. Just let me speak to her.
She ain’t allowed visitors-
I’m not visitin’! I’m tryin’ to sort things out-
Excuse me!...Can I help here? Tooley pushes through the women.
I only just found out...A question of trespass, I gather? On Ford property?
Who are you?
(pushing ID over) I represent Ford Motors, Sir, and we have no desire to press charges here. (Rita stares at Tooley, immediately uneasy) Protest is a basic right in all free and democratic countries.
There’s also a matter of assault-

Is that so? Well, I’m quite sure it was a minor thing. And with all these ladies here as witnesses, plus the view of another of my employees who clearly saw the incident with the middle aged woman...I’m sure you’d be just as happy as me if it went right away. The clerk hesitates, then bolts from his desk into a back room. Tooley turns, smiles.
Robert Tooley, Mrs O’Grady. A pleasure to meet you. She’s shocked he knows her name. Then Tooley produces a card from an inner pocket. He holds it out-

Anytime you wanna come in, have a chat with me... (she takes the card) Talk about settling this thing- (she looks him in the eye) Just give me a call. (starts to go; looks back) It's my job to make things happen, Mrs O'Grady. I can make all sorts of things happen. And he’s gone.
Christ...I thought Boris Karloff was scary. Rita nods, gathering herself and her tumbling emotions.
It’s fine. We can handle him...Shows how much they’re frightened of us...Sendin’ in the heavy brigade- A cheer of support. Rita makes to say more- But a voice cuts through.
Can we go now...I wanna go home. Connie is there; standing by an inner door which closes behind her. She is visibly upset. The girls flock to her. A half beat and Rita, a little awkward, goes, too.
93A EXT. CONNIE’S HOUSE 93A Connie enters her house.
INT. CONNIE’S HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON 94 Connie closes her door. She looks pale. A second as she gathers herself. Then she walks towards the sitting room, calling out, brightly-
I’m back, George- But there is no-one there, his chair empty.
George? She passes into the kitchen. Nothing. And now she’s looking slightly anxious. She calls generally, to the house...
I’m home, love- And she hurries from the kitchen to the stairs. We see her run up them.
George! Then we hear her upstairs. Front bedroom, back bedroom and running back down the stairs. She looks scared.
George wanders across a bleak, barren expanse of open ground. His steps are jerky, ragged. He looks wretched.
We hear shouts from the girls. They are calling George's name as they search the estate. Rita and Connie appear at the foot of a twitchell.
Christ-
He’1l turn up-
I said. I said I’d be back at two-
Connie-
(shouts ) George!
Rita looks stressed but knows she must remain calm.
Graham, still in school uniform, carrying a football, heads home. He frowns; recognising the figure sitting on a fly tipped bench. It is George. Graham moves over.
Hello Mr Andrews...You alright? George says nothing. There is a hint of spittle in the corner of his mouth. Graham is unsure. He glances round, then sits beside George.

Just been playin’ football. I was Bobby Moore... (nothing from George) I should get home for me tea- He starts to move. But George reaches out and takes his hand. (through gritted teeth) That 's-as-—it-should-be!...Try and understand that. Please. What you’re talkin’ about now...what I’ve been fightin’ for, the last few weeks...Same thing...Rights. Not privileges. She marches off and Eddie watches her go. He sways, as if he has taken a punch.
The last of the girls climbs onto a coach. Rita looks back at the streets of Dagenham and climbs on also-

The coach is full. Rita’s seat is at the front as usual. The seat next to her, Connie’s, is empty. Rita catches Brenda’s eye and then she sits, alone. INT. RITA’S HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON 141 Eddie sits at the kitchen table, thinking. He looks shocked. He blinks, noticing the unpacked camping gear leant against a couple of protest placards. He exhales slowly. But then, Graham enters the room. He sits next to his father. Eddie looks at him. Graham smiles. It’s fine. A long moment and Eddie straightens.
EXT. NEIGHBOUR’S HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON 142 The kids stand with a woman on her doorstep and wave as Eddie zooms off on his motorbike. He doesn’t wave back.
A hotel with a plush facade, displaying a sign: The Tadmarton Park Hotel, Weymouth, Dorset Welcomes The Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions.
The ballroom is crowded with Union delegates as the Chair, up on stage, a northerner, consults his notes.

Very good, gentlemen. And that brings us to our main item...The ongoing dispute at Ford Motors...Can I call on Monty Taylor, Senior Convenor, Ford Dagenham. The chairman squints. And out of the darkness comes Monty. He mounts the stage and moves across to the Chair. He whispers and then crosses to the lectern.
Thank you Mr Chairman...I shall try and be brief- He looks to the darkened hall, a glint in his eye.
Eddie jumps off his bike and looks wildly round: Shit! The seafront is a mass of hotels.
Monty is pushing on, scared, but desperate.
-Of course we must represent all our members...But me must also remember we live in a democracy. And in a democracy, the wishes of the majority must always hold sway. Therefore-
Monty Taylor! You two faced, hypocritical, toe rag!
A kerfuffle by the door. Monty squints into the darkness. The lights come on. The Dagenham contingent are there, Eileen by the switch, banners at the ready.
Now hang on-

No, you hang on- More rowdiness and shouts of Judas. The whole hall hums. Several delegates stand to see what’s happening. Monty has moved to the front of the stage and calls out for the girls to sit down and that he’1ll explain, while they cal back at him. Finally Monty returns and shouts into the microphone.
Be quiet! The noise shocks everyone into silence. Monty is embarrassed and moderates his voice. MONTY (CONT’D) Sorry...Gentlemen...We’1l sort this out amongst ourselves later-

(shouts; stands) Hey, Monty! I’ve seen more of their mugs on the front pages these last few weeks than you’ve managed in twenty years! (laughter from crowd) I wouldnae mind hearin’ from ‘em. Shouts of support. Monty looks terrified.

No- More shouts of support. Monty shakes his head. EXT. SEAFRONT —- EVENING 147 Eddie walks down the seafront and stops. Parked up ahead is a coach...From Dagenham. He runs past it and into the Hotel outside which it is parked.

More shouts. Monty looks trapped. Then the sound of slow stamping and clapping. Louder and louder. Then Brenda, Eileen and the others step aside. Rita is there. She walks towards the platform. And Monty looks sunk.
Eddie looks for a sign and runs towards the doors which lead into the hall.

Eddie bursts into the hall and stops right at the back. Rita is at the lectern, a light on her. All around is still. She makes to speak then stops, gathering herself; all of the emotion of the last few days sweeping over her. She stares at the people in the hall, their faces turned to her. Waiting...

My best friend lost her husband recently. Durin’ the war he was a gunner in Fifty Squadron in the RAF. He got shot down one time...on a raid to Essen and even though he managed to bail out, he was badly injured. I asked him once, why he’d joined the raf and he said...they got the best women... (Laughter in the hall. She nods, upset) Which they did... Eddie stares at Rita
But then he said, you had to do somethin’. And he’d always wanted to go up in a plane... Her jaw tightens; she feels the cause start to flood through her veins.

You had to do somethin’...That was a given. Cause it was a matter of principle. You had to stand up; do what was right, ‘cause otherwise you wouldn’t be able to look yourself in the mirror. (stares at hall) When did that change? When did we, in this country, start bein’ happy, to do nothin’? On what day did we decide we had no duty to fairness no more? (The hall is silent. She nods slightly) It has NOT changed. (MORE)

That is NOT us...It is not you...And we are only in this situation now, where women get paid less money than men for doing the same work... (lets it sink in. Nods) -because we was tricked. Those in power kept tellin’ us: it’s fine. You don’t need to do the right thing cause there’s nothin’ needs fixin’. And they said it for so long, we ended up believin’ it was right....Well it ain’t right! Calls of support. Heads nod in agreement.

It was wrong at the start, it’s wrong now, and it’ll be wrong forever!- (shouts of agreement) -unless you back us, you stand up, you remember who you are and you accept, that this is a matter of principle. Women are entitled to the same rates of pay as men. And that is it. No matter the cost, no Matter the difficulty, no matter them that are gonna lose out, no human being should be punished in the workplace cause’ve how they was born! (Cheers. Rita calls above them-) We are the working classes. The men and the women. We are the furnace which fires the world and without us no-body earns tuppence h’appenny! (big cheer) We are not separated by sex, only by the will of those who are not prepared to go into battle for what is right - and those who are! The hall erupts. And leaps to its feet. Eddie sways.

Delegates pour out, talking excitedly about what they have just witnessed. We briefly see Eddie again, swallowed up by the crowd, being pushed backwards. And then we see our girls, emerging thrilled and elated. We hear odd snatches of conversation above a huge wall of chatter-
(to another woman) I’m tellin’ you! You can see ‘em! Scorch marks right up the curtains where Monty’s arse caught fire- The woman laughs. Rita smiles. Her chest still heaves. Eileen grabs her wrist.
Come on, let’s have a drink-
We got no money-
We’re all signin’ it to Monty’s room- The girls laugh. The scots delegate pats Rita on the back. Some speech. Rita nods, but she is exhausted. Brenda smiles at her.
Hey! Come on...You’re allowed to unwind a bit, you know

(nods ) Yeah. ‘Cept we ain’t there yet, Brenda- She stops. She is looking over Brenda’s shoulder, to the other side of revolving doors, where she can see, on the spot where he has been spat out, Eddie. He stares in at Rita. Then, suddenly, he turns and hurries off-
Rita runs after the retreating Eddie. She calls out to him.
Eddie...Eddie! (he finally stops; turns) What you doin’ here? He looks at her; slightly confused. Then...

I...come to say sorry. I mean...I thought...about what you said and- (shrugs ) You’re right, I suppose...You are right. (nods ) And it is amazin’ what you done...Rita O'Grady. And I wanna back you...I was gonna tell you that. Only then I come in when you was speakin’ and I heard you and...you was...huge...you was...like a force- He can’t express it. Then he looks at her fondly and smiles.

And then I thought... (shrugs ) Not sure me backin’ you makes that much difference to be quiet honest. Where you are now... (serious; positive) Anyway. You get back to your meeting or whatever you gotta do. I should... He nods, vaguely over his shoulder and sets off, walking-
Eddie! He turns again. She shakes her head.
You’ve said some stupid things in your time but... She runs to him, embraces him and kisses him hard on the mouth. She steps back. He looks stunned.
Of course you backin’ me makes a difference. It makes all the difference in the world. She kisses him again.
Mrs Castle is holding back the slightest of smiles. She is looking at a sheet of paper on her desk while the undersecretaries wait in a line.
“The bloody unions are back in line”-
It’s verbatim.
Our man was there.

Well, well, well- (looks to them) So the strike remains solid. And meanwhile, five thousand men have now been laid off and the country has lost export orders worth 8 million pounds... (checks notes) 8 million.
She looks back to the undersecretaries.
It really does seem time to call in Sir Jack.
Good...I‘’1l1 do that then. I’1l appoint a Court of Inquiry, which he can oversee. And let’s hope that does the job. She smiles. The men glance at each other and stand.
Oh, yes. And one other thing...Set up a meeting will you.
Minister?
With the machinists. Their leaders. The men glance at each other.
Pardon me?
I want to meet them. At my St James's Square Offices...At the earliest opportunity.
But— Mrs Castle looks at them quizzically. Yes?
The Minister doesn’t. Do that. Never has done.
It'll just encourage them.
Give credence to their cause. She looks at them. Long beat. She inhales. Then:
I’m what’s known as a fiery red head...I hate to make this a matter of appearance...go all womanly on you but...there you have it. And me standing up like this- (gets to her feet) (MORE)

Is in fact, just that red headed fieriness, leaping to the fore... (voice rises furiously) Credence! I will give credence to their cause? My God. Their cause already has credence. It’s equal pay. Equal pay is common justice. And if you weren’t such a bunch of egotistical, chauvinistic, bigoted dunderheads, you’d realise it-

This is an office run by incompetents. And I am sick and tired of being patronised, spoken down to and generally indulged as if I was the May Queen! (one of the men holds up a tremulous finger, as if to make a point-) Set up the meeting! The men scatter.
Tooley glares-
Whaddya mean, The Secretary of State is gonna see the women? On whose say so? Hopkins faces Tooley; scared.
On her own, I gather...Apparently, Mrs Castle’s quite a forceful woman-
Is she! He marches across the office and picks up his phone.
What’re you doing-?
I represent Ford Motors. We are the biggest car manufacturer in the world. We pump millions of pounds into the UK economy... he dial (he *tWORE)
I think it’s time my bosses started reminding one or two people of that fact.

Eddie’s motorcycle pulls up outside Rita’s house. Albert waits by the door. Rita looks concerned and quickly jumps out of the side car, hurrying over to him. For once he doesn’t look entirely in control of his emotions-

There’s no need to panic, Rita. Only I’ve had a call...From Mrs Castle’s office- Eddie is clambering off the bike but turns suddenly as he hears a sharp scream of excitement. He looks down the drive to Rita who is turned to him, an expression of sheer delight on her face-

Bloody ‘ell! She grins, thrilled! INT. RITA’S HOUSE - DAY 155 Now Rita looks concerned as she roots through her wardrobe. She pulls out a dress and turns, holding it up. Albert sits on a chair beside Eddie, Eddie still in his bike gear, sitting on the bed, both gazing across at the impromptu fashion show like rabbits caught in a full headlight glare.
Too short. She nods in agreement. Then she looks back and selects another outfit. This she holds up.
Too formal. She nods and she grabs another. She holds this up. But this time she doesn’t say anything. She looks to the lads. Albert jumps at the opportunity-
Lovely...that is... (to Eddie) Innit? That’s-
Yeah. They both nod. Her face falls
You hate it... She looks back to the wardrobe. The lads glance at each other appalled.
I ain’t got anythin’ that’s right- And then Rita stops; has an idea...

Hopkins is back at home. He stares sickly at the front page of the Telegraph which records the ongoing horror of Ford's plummeting sales figures. Then the door bell rings. Hopkins waits for Lisa to answer. But it rings again. He sighs and stands, crossing to the door. He opens it. Rita. He is stunned.
S’'alright. I ain’t come to see you. It’s your missus I wanna talk to. Lisa steps forward from behind Hopkins.
Rita...What are you doing here?
Rita?!
I need a favour. Hopkins is agog. Lisa nods.
Come inside-
(annoyed) Lisa-
What!?
Her look is hard; combative. He has not seen it before. She holds his gaze, furiously and he steps meekly to one side. Rita enters the house.

Harold Wilson puffs on his pipe as his official motor sets off around St James’s Square. Mrs Castle settles next to him, having just got in. Wilson looks tense and when Mrs Castle raises an enquiring eyebrow, he gets straight to it-
Have you or have you not invited the Ford women to your offices? Mrs Castle hesitates, momentarily. Then:
Prime minister-
I have just spent the last half an hour on the phone to Henry Ford the Second, reassuring him that my government is not on the side of the strikers-
It’s not a question of sides. We have to grasp the nettle-
By aligning ourselves with the machinists? (she makes to deny this) I wanted you to fix this! Not to make it worse-!
And I will fix it! If you’d just... (can’t help it) Bloody well support me! This shocks them both. But Wilson can see her passion. He nods. Go on.
I can resolve this dispute. I can get the women working again... but I am going to have to tell them that I agree with their cause. He understands instantly-
No. Barbara, please-
10.08.09 ORANGE REVISIONS 105aA
You know their right. He sighs; his shoulders slump.
Now is not the time-
Harold, we talked about this in the nineteen fifties, You were adamant-—
I wasn’t running the country then! She looks away. Disappointed in him. He sighs. Long beat.

HAROLD WILSON (CONT’D) See the women. If that’s what you want to do. (she starts to speak; grateful) But! Whatever you do, do not upset Ford! I’m enough trouble with the Americans as it is. She nods, knowing that she is on a tightrope.
Rita strides through Dagenham. Pull back. She wears Lisa’s Biba dress. Ahead, the other girls wait for her.
The rather splendid exterior of Mrs Castle’s offices.
The undersecretaries are struggling with a sofa. They put it down, then straighten. They are sweating.

There. Perfect...Actually...Maybe it was better where we had it before- (The men exchange glances) Oh...dizzy me. The men stagger back with the sofa and she turns away. Up close we see she is nervous. She looks back-
Just the armchairs, then... (she disappears from view) And I want plenty of sherry.

EXT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY 163 The girls walk towards St James’s Square, followed by the press. A second crowd of photographers and a camera crew, already in-situ, rush forwards to envelop them. Behind, the press who have dogged them all day, also shove forwards and a scrum ensues. Before long, one or two of the girls look overwhelmed and panicky.
If you could just...can we get through please- (she, too, is struggling) You’re blockin’ the way. You-
Make some room, for God’s sake- Rita stops. Looks across. Connie is coming towards her, shoving reporters aside.
Connie- The door opens and an undersecretary steps out.
Ladies. Good morning...Could you keep back please, gentlemen- He and a couple more of the staff shove the press back.
I’m sorry I’m late. The two women stare, Rita’s eyes fill. They embrace.
163 Cont.EXT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY
Rita! Rita! Can we have a final comment-
Rita-
All of the girls are through the cordon and the reporters are pushed back. But still they look formidable-
Rita! Is equal pay really a possibility?
What if Mrs Castle says no deal?
How will you cope?
Cope? How will we cope? She is aware of Connie beside her. Eileen, Sandra and Brenda, too. Rita looks back to the reporter.
We’re women. Now don’t ask such stupid questions. Rita turns to Connie and leads the girls back inside.

Mrs Castle checks the room; with sofas and armchairs arranged in a circle it now looks like a living room rather than a meeting place. She takes a deep breath and crosses to a large armoire at the back of the room. She opens it and selects a jacket from her closet. She plumps for something rather old. She looks at herself in the door mirror. Very sober. Then she checks shoes. The pair we've seen on several occasions are discarded and a plainer pair popped on. There is knock on the door. An under secretary comes in

Minister, there’s a slight problem. Mrs Castle turns to the secretary. INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY 164A Mrs Castle walks into a smaller room. A man stands with his back to us. He turns, it’s Tooley.
Mrs Castle.
Mr Tooley - I wasn’t expecting you. They shake hands.
But you are meeting the women?
I think it’s time I listened to their argument. If you’d care to wait I'll inform you of any decisions we make. She turns. Tooley watches her; his jaw suddenly tightens-
You know, we basically want the same thing, Mrs Castle...you and I- She stops and turns
We want to see Ford Motors employing British workers.
Ford is a vital part of our economy, I’m well aware of that-
Then don’t make us go elsewhere to build our cars... It wobbles her. He smiles.
If you don’t help us hold the line here and support us in our efforts to combat the constant strikes which undermine our ability to make cars at a profit...we will take our factories elsewhere.
Are you threatening me, Mr Tooley?

I’m just trying to stop 40,000 people from losing their jobs, Mrs Castle. That's how many people we employ in this country...Neither of us wanna take that risk...surely? She holds his gaze. Then she turns away.
Mrs Castle closes the door behind her and takes a deep breath.

Brenda and Sandra look out of a window, pointing out the sights. But they’re nervous. As is Connie who glances to the door. But Rita, who is beside her, sitting on a sofa, can concentrate only on her friend. Finally-
Connie- Connie turns. Rita speaks with a hushed voice. She smiles. Then fudges it-
Thanks for comin’.
Connie smiles. And Rita immediately leans closer in-
I’m so sorry-—

No! Don’t. It’s me that needs to apologise- (Rita frowns) I loved George. More than anything. But he’s gone now. And it’s the right thing. I thought that straightaway. And I felt guilty...and I took it out on you but... (nods head) He ain’t sufferin’ and...he is better out of it. I know that...Deep down. And you gotta trust them feelin’s. Ain’t you? Gotta follow your gut...You taught us that. Rita is amazed but before she can react, the door is opened and an undersecretary is there.
The Minister will see you now- The women all look at each other.
They walk into the main office where Mrs Castle is waiting in front of the grand fireplace.
Mrs Castle? She turns and smiles
I am...And you’re Mrs O’Grady. I recognise you from the news. She crosses and they shake.
I’m pleased to meet you.
And me, you. Mrs Castle looks to the others.
Sorry. This is Connie, Brenda and Sandra.
I’m delighted you could all come They all nod. Mrs Castle’s brain is racing.
Please take a seat. Would you care for a sherry? Mrs Castle, nods to a strategically placed undersecretary.
You ain’t got whiskey, have you? The girls look to Brenda thunderously.
Tooley is waiting still. He is brought a second cup of tea. He looks irritated.
Sugar?
No. The undersecretary takes the empty and leaves the full cup. Tooley looks to the door. All alpha male
Mrs Castle places her jacket on her chair. She’s delaying. Then she turns to Rita who sits directly opposite, a small table between them.

I’ve been following your dispute very closely. And I want to say how proud I am of the battle you’ve fought. I fully support the struggle for equal pay. The girls look to each other, flushed with hope.
And you will have it...But in time.
What?
Industry is going to object. The Lords’11l kick up a fuss. The press’ll have a field day...It isn’t going to be easy-
What is, that’s worth havin’? Mrs Castle makes to retort then stops and considers the girls. This is difficult. But she drives on-
Return to work, get back to your machines and then you have my word that I will push forward with your fight-
No! The girls were all thinking it but Rita’s vehemence still surprises.
Mrs O’Grady-
That ain’t good enough- (Barbara makes to speak) We want somethin’ now! Somethin’ solid-
But-—
You got the authority, you- (upset) We thought...seein’ you, we’d-
In politics you sometimes have to play the long game-
We ain’t politicians! We’re workin’ women. And so are you! Mrs Castle blinks. Rita too. A beat. Then Mrs Castle straightens.
Very well. What would it take...? To get you back.
Excuse me?
The something solid...And mark well, I say some thing, not everything.
We'd need...guarantee of an Equal Pay Act and...an immediate and...considerable movement towards the male rate at Ford. Mrs Castle considers them. Her eyes narrow.
Seventy five per cent?
Ninety. Mrs Castle’s eyes widen.

You’re putting me in a very difficult position... 167A INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES ANTE ROOM Mrs Castle closes the door behind her. Her brain races. She turns to an undersecretary in the room.
Get me the Prime Minister.
He picks up the phone. Mrs Castle's jaw tightens.
Tooley waits, fidgeting. An undersecretary sticks his head round the door with a teapot and an enquiring expression.
Whadd’ya think? The undersecretary ducks away.
The women sit on the edges of their seats and wait. Rita feels self conscious.
I wasn't too...aggressive?
Naah. (looks to Sandra) They have got rid of hangin’ ain't they? Connie simply squeezes Rita’s hand. INT. BARBARA CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES, ANTE ROOM - 16
The undersecretary puts down the phone.

He’s on a plane. Won’t land until this evening. Mrs Castle says nothing. Just exhales, slowly. Then she looks to the opposite ends of the room. Two doors. Two choices. She takes a deep breath. INT. MRS CASTLE’S WESTMINSTER OFFICES - DAY 167E Mrs Castle strides into Tooley’s room. Tooley immediately makes to speak- but Mrs Castle gets there first.

That risk; you were talking about, Mr Tooley. I’m going to have to take it. (he frowns) All women are entitled to equal pay and I intend to begin the process of enshrining that fact in law. Whatever the cost. (Tooley is ashen) (MORE)

So, the question is...do you want to wait until it is Law before you get your machinists back to work, or do you want to make a gesture now and see production resume immediately? Tooley stares at Mrs Castle. Endgame. Who will back down?
Eileen, Monica and the other women wait patiently with their banners. Albert appears and dispenses beers.
The women stare at empty glasses. Brenda takes a pull on her whiskey.
I’m gonna miss all this. The girls smile but they’re so nervous. And then the door opens. All heads turn and Mrs Castle walks slowly into the room.
We have a deal.
Suddenly, Barbara looks uneasy. She shakes her head. The girls look worried.
Rita is stunned. She sees Mrs Castle’s twinkling smile. And she, along with the girls, smiles.
Thank you! Mrs Castle grabs a glass and toasts with Rita. Brenda smiles and looks to Connie who is grinning, too.
The women look tired as well as happy as they walk into the sunlight. Mrs Castle stops as they are greeted by camera flashes, and turns to Rita.
That's Biba... I saw it in a magazine- Rita nods to Mrs Castle’s outfit.
And that’s C and A. I’ve got one at home... Seems we all dressed up... And you dressed down... Who did that put at an advantage do you think? Mrs Castle laughs.
After you.
Oh, no, young lady. After you. Mrs Castle indicates that Rita should step forward first. And Rita moves towards the crowd.
Black and white TV footage. Mrs Castle stands with the girls. She clears her throat.

Thank you...Thank you very much...I’m delighted to say that following our talks this afternoon, getting down to the nitty gritty, the 187 Ford machinists will be going back to work on the lst of July. They will get an immediate pay rise of 7d an hour which will put them at 92% of the male rate. However, this is not an end to it. As a result of our discussion, I can announce that the government is fully committed to the creation of an Equal Pay Act and by the Autumn of this year, I guarantee appropriate legislation will be put into place to ensure that that act becomes law. She steps back. Cameras flash and reporters call out. Rita breathes deeply, absorbing the scene.
She places her arms around Connie and with Sandra and Eileen and Brenda, they form up as a group. They all beam. SNAP. And the picture freezes.

head_text.subj: THE STRIKE BY THE DAGENHAM SEWING MACHINISTS AND THE
SUBSEQUENT SETTLEMENT NEGOTIATED THAT AFTERNOON WITH MRS
BARBARA CASTLE DID INDEED LEAD TO THE INTRODUCTION OF AN
EQUAL PAY ACT. IT BECAME LAW IN 1970.

text: The deserted factory. But then a bike comes over the hill. A single bike. A woman is on it. Then comes another and another. The women are leading the workforce back and soon the whole road is awash with bikes and people, all buffeted together, a vast sea of humanity, sweeping down the road, back to their jobs.
